1__page_18_Figure_0.jpeg.caption: The figure presents a line graph depicting the relationship between the critical temperature \(T_c\) (in Kelvin) and the resistance ratio \([p(300K)/p(25K)]\) for approximately 130 Nb-Ge films. The data, gathered by Testardi and colleagues, show a pronounced correlation between \(T_c\) and the resistance ratio across various sputtering conditions, compositions, and film thicknesses, demonstrating a universal trend. A notable finding is that superconductivity is absent when the resistance ratio is less than one. The theoretical curve shown aligns well with the experimental data, highlighting the consistency of the underlying theoretical model with observed phenomena【4:0†source】.
queries: Here are some search queries that can be generated based on the figure and the context provided:
"Experimental methods for analyzing resistance ratios in superconducting Nb-Ge films."

"Impact of sputtering conditions on resistance ratio and superconductivity in Nb-Ge films."
"Theoretical models explaining universal trends in superconductor film data."

1__page_16_Figure_0.jpeg.caption: The figure displays the relationship between the critical temperature \(T_c\) and the residual resistivity \(\rho_0\) at \(22^\circ K\) for Nb\(_3\)Sn and Nb\(_3\)Ge, showcasing data from Wiesmann et al. The experimental data points are represented along with theoretical predictions, which match closely with the trends. The figure illustrates that as \(\rho_0\) increases, \(T_c\) decreases for both materials, indicating a distinct superconducting degradation with increasing resistivity. This relationship highlights the sensitivity of these superconductors to disorder, providing insights into the underlying mechanisms affecting their superconducting properties【12:0†source】.
